deliberation: Looked for metaphors, similes, and metonymy. The verse has hunting imagery applied to leaders ('snare' and 'net'), which are clear metaphors. The calls to hear (priests, house of Israel, house of the king) are standard vocatives, not figurative in themselves. I treat 'snare' and 'net' as two distinct but parallel metaphors.

instances.english_text: For you have been a snare to Mizpah
target: Israel’s leaders and religious establishment associated with Mizpah
human leadership of the northern kingdom
vehicle: a snare set for prey at Mizpah
ground: they secretly catch and harm those who come there
posture: prophetic accusation portraying leaders as dangerous traps
instances.explanation: The leaders are equated with a snare at Mizpah, depicting them as devices that trap and destroy those who come to them spiritually, rather than guiding them rightly.

instances.english_text: and a net spread out over Tabor
target: same corrupt leadership and cult centered around Mount Tabor
vehicle: a net spread over a high place catching unwary creatures
ground: they cover the place and capture those who approach, leaving no escape
posture: depicts their religious influence as a lethal ambush
instances.explanation: The leadership and their cult at Tabor are likened to a net that covers and traps, emphasizing how thoroughly they ensnare the people in sin.

deliberation: Examined whether 'trappers' and 'pitfalls' are literal or figurative. In context with v.1's hunting imagery, they extend the metaphor for corrupt plotting. Also 'I am discipline/rebuke to all of them' is God metaphorically identified with chastisement, not literally being 'discipline' as a substance.

instances.english_text: For when trappers dug deep pitfalls
target: corrupt leaders and their devious schemes
vehicle: trappers digging deep pits to catch animals
ground: they prepare hidden, dangerous traps to ensnare victims
posture: exposes their sin as calculated ambush rather than accident
instances.explanation: The leaders’ deep, secretive wickedness is compared to hunters digging deep traps, highlighting the deliberate and concealed nature of their sin.

instances.english_text: and I was [or am] discipline/reproof to all of them
target: YHWH’s actions toward the corrupt people
vehicle: discipline/reproof as an abstract corrective force
ground: his dealings function as corrective punishment and warning
posture: portrays God as wholly oriented toward correction, not indulgence
instances.explanation: God says he is 'discipline' to them, identifying himself with the chastening process to stress that his actions toward them are entirely corrective and punitive.

deliberation: Considered whether language is purely covenantal or figurative. The key expression 'you have fornicated, O Ephraim' is Hosea’s standard metaphor of sexual immorality for idolatry and covenant-breaking, not literal prostitution.

instances.english_text: Behold, you have fornicated, O Ephraim
ground: both betray an exclusive relationship and join oneself to another illegitimately
posture: frames idolatry as deeply personal betrayal of God
instances.explanation: Idolatry and covenant treachery are described as 'fornication,' casting Israel’s religious apostasy in the emotionally charged terms of sexual infidelity.

deliberation: Looked for explicit metaphor/simile. The striking phrase is 'a spirit of whoredom is within them', which is not a literal entity inhabiting them but a figurative way to describe an inner disposition toward unfaithfulness; the 'spirit' here is metaphorical and personified.

instances.english_text: Because a spirit of whoredom is within them
target: the inner moral and religious disposition of the people
vehicle: a 'spirit of whoredom' dwelling inside a person
ground: it drives behavior from within, like a possessing influence
posture: portrays their unfaithfulness as deeply internalized and controlling
instances.explanation: Their persistent unfaithfulness is described as if an inner 'spirit of whoredom' lives in them, personifying their wayward inclination as a possessing force.

deliberation: Detected (1) 'the pride of Israel testifies/answers to his face' where pride behaves as a witness—personification; (2) 'Israel and Ephraim will stumble in their iniquity' using physical stumbling as a metaphor for moral and national failure.

instances.english_text: Israel’s pride shall answer/testify before his very eyes
target: inner moral state of the nation
vehicle: a witness or advocate who speaks/answers in court
ground: the very thing he relies on becomes evidence against him
pride as incriminating proof in judgment
posture: portrays pride as turning into Israel’s own accuser
instances.explanation: Israel’s 'pride' is personified as a witness that speaks right in his face, emphasizing how his arrogance itself will testify against him in judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיִשְׂרָאֵל וְאֶפְרַיִם יִכָּשְׁלוּ בַּעֲוֹנָם כָּשַׁל גַּם־יְהוּדָה עִמָּם
instances.english_text: Israel and Ephraim shall stumble in their iniquity; Judah also has stumbled with them
target: Israel’s and Judah’s moral and political downfall
vehicle: a person stumbling and falling while walking
ground: sin causes loss of stability and leads to collapse
posture: warns that sin inevitably leads to collapse
instances.explanation: Their sin is said to make them 'stumble,' using physical tripping as a metaphor for the destabilizing and ruinous effect of iniquity on the nations.

deliberation: The cultic action ('they will go with their sheep and cattle to seek YHWH') is literal sacrificial language. The figurative element is 'He has withdrawn/cast Himself off from them'—God depicted as someone who has removed Himself spatially, a metaphor for relational abandonment.

instances.english_text: He has withdrawn from them / He has cast Himself off from them
target: YHWH’s relational stance toward the people
vehicle: a person disengaging and pulling away from others
ground: there is no longer accessible presence or help
posture: presents God as deliberately distancing Himself in judgment
instances.explanation: God is described as having 'withdrawn' from them, using spatial separation as a metaphor for the loss of His relational presence and favor despite their sacrifices.

deliberation: Considered whether 'alien children' is literal or metaphorical; it may be either, so I did not treat it as clearly figurative. The clearest figure is 'the new moon shall devour them and their portions,' where a calendrical time or festival is personified as a devouring agent of judgment.

instances.english_text: Now the new moon shall devour them with their portions
target: the people and their allotted possessions under impending judgment
vehicle: a devouring entity associated with the new moon/time
ground: what is associated with the coming time/festival will consume them totally
posture: warns that an approaching appointed time will completely consume what they rely on
instances.explanation: The 'new moon' is personified as a devourer that eats them and their portions, portraying the imminent time of judgment as a ravenous consumer of their lives and inheritances.

deliberation: Most elements (trumpet, ram’s horn) fit literal war-alarm imagery. The notable figurative element is the place name 'Beth-aven' used for Bethel, a pejorative renaming ('house of wickedness' instead of 'house of God'), functioning via wordplay/metonymy to characterize the cult there.

instances.english_text: Beth-aven
target: the sanctuary town Bethel and its cult
vehicle: moral evaluation encoded in a name
ground: the sanctuary has become characterized by worthlessness and sin
its worship is empty, corrupt, vain
posture: deliberately insults and redefines the sanctuary by a punning name
instances.explanation: Calling Bethel 'Beth-aven' replaces 'house of God' with 'house of wickedness,' a metonymic wordplay that brands the cult there as worthless and evil.

deliberation: Checked for metaphor/simile. 'Ephraim shall be for desolation on a day of rebuke' is straightforward prophetic prediction; 'day of chastisement' is an image but conventional prophetic idiom, not an explicit metaphor beyond normal usage. I do not see a strong, discrete figurative expression that stands apart from literal judgment language.

Identified two explicit כ- comparisons. (1) 'the princes of Judah were like boundary-shifters' is a simile equating their behavior with land thieves; (2) 'I will pour out my wrath on them like water' is a simile using water imagery for overwhelming judgment.

instances.english_text: The officers of Judah have acted like shifters of field boundaries
target: the princes’ political and religious abuses
vehicle: those who move boundary markers to steal land
ground: both violate God-ordained order and rob others of their proper share
encroachment, theft, disregard for divine law
posture: casts their leadership as brazen lawbreaking against their own people
instances.explanation: The princes of Judah are compared to people who move boundary stones, underscoring that their leadership robs and wrongs others like land thieves violating Torah.

instances.english_text: On them I will pour out My wrath like water
target: God’s coming judgment on these leaders
vehicle: a gush or flood of liquid
ground: it will be overwhelming, inescapable, and unrestrained
posture: emphasizes the sheer intensity and totality of the judgment
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is likened to water poured out, conveying how overwhelmingly and unstoppably judgment will fall on the unjust leaders.

deliberation: Saw two kinds of non-literal language: (1) 'oppressed, crushed in judgment' uses physical crushing as metaphor for loss of justice; (2) 'he went after command/futility' is a standard Hebrew idiom for following human precepts or idols, not literal walking, so I mark it as idiom with metaphorical movement imagery.

instances.english_text: Ephraim is oppressed, crushed in judgment
target: Ephraim’s deprived legal and social situation
vehicle: a body or object being pressed and crushed
ground: subjected to overpowering force leaving them broken
helplessness, severe damage, inability to stand
posture: depicts the nation as severely broken by the very justice meant to uphold it
instances.explanation: The phrase portrays Ephraim as physically 'crushed' by judgment, using bodily injury as a metaphor for the severe breakdown of justice and wellbeing.

instances.english_text: Because he has willingly gone after command/futility
target: Ephraim’s choice to follow human precepts or idols
vehicle: following a path after a leader
ground: to 'go after' is to give allegiance and obedience to that thing
imitation, submission, pursuit of a guide
directing life according to a pattern
posture: condemns Ephraim’s deliberate alignment with worthless commands
instances.explanation: ‘Going after command’ is an idiom using walking imagery for allegiance and obedience, depicting Ephraim as choosing to follow man-made or futile directives instead of God.

deliberation: Both clauses have explicit כ- comparisons: God is 'like a moth to Ephraim' and 'like decay to the house of Judah.' These are two related but distinct similes, picturing divine judgment as slow, internal deterioration.

instances.english_text: For it is I who am like rot/moth to Ephraim
vehicle: a moth that eats away fabric from within
ground: works quietly and gradually until the object is ruined
posture: presents God’s judgment as inevitable, though not always immediately visible
instances.explanation: God compares Himself to a moth toward Ephraim, implying a slow, inward eating away of strength rather than a single sudden blow.

instances.english_text: and like decay to the house of Judah
target: God’s effect on Judah through judgment
vehicle: rottenness/decay eating away a structure or bone
ground: silent internal disintegration leading to collapse
posture: underscores that Judah’s decline is God’s own work of judgment
instances.explanation: God likens Himself to 'decay' for Judah, picturing His judgment as an internal rot that gradually undermines the nation’s strength.

deliberation: The whole verse extends a sickness metaphor: Ephraim sees his 'sickness' and Judah his 'wound', and seeks 'healing' from Assyria and the 'great king'. These are not literal medical conditions but figurative for political/spiritual trouble; they form one coherent illness metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיַּרְא אֶפְרַיִם אֶת־חָלְיוֹ וִיהוּדָה אֶת־מְזֹרוֹ ... הוּא לֹא יוּכַל לִרְפֹּא לָכֶם וְלֹא־יִגְהֶה מִכֶּם מָזוֹר
instances.english_text: When Ephraim became aware of his sickness, Judah of his sores ... he will never be able to cure you, will not heal you of your sores
target: the political, social, and spiritual crises of Ephraim and Judah
vehicle: bodily sickness, sores, and medical healing
ground: they are in a weakened, damaged condition needing remedy, which Assyria cannot provide
vulnerability, dependence on an effective healer, insufficiency of wrong remedies
posture: mocks their seeking political 'medicine' from Assyria instead of from God
instances.explanation: The nations’ deep troubles are portrayed as sickness and sores, and reliance on Assyria as seeking a doctor who cannot heal, highlighting both their vulnerability and the futility of their chosen remedy.

deliberation: Detected two similes: God is 'like a lion to Ephraim' and 'like a young lion to the house of Judah.' The subsequent tearing and carrying off language fills out the same predatory imagery, but I treat the two explicit comparisons as distinct instances for the two targets.

instances.english_text: For I am like a lion to Ephraim
vehicle: a lion attacking prey, tearing and going away with it
ground: sudden, violent, unstoppable attack with no rescue
ferocity, power, inevitability of the kill
posture: portrays God as their terrifying predator rather than protector
instances.explanation: God compares Himself to a lion toward Ephraim, emphasizing the violent, irresistible nature of the coming judgment.

instances.english_text: and like a young lion to the house of Judah
vehicle: a young lion (lion cub) with predatory strength
ground: energetic, powerful attack that carries prey away
posture: signals Judah is not exempt but will also face predatory judgment
prophetic equalization of north and south
instances.explanation: By likening Himself to a young lion toward Judah, God depicts His judgment as an energetic, powerful attack that will seize them with no rescuer.

deliberation: Considered 'I will return to my place' as anthropomorphic metaphor for divine withdrawal, but the clearest figurative expression is 'they will seek my face,' which uses physical searching and 'face' as a metaphor for seeking God’s presence/favor in distress.

instances.english_text: till they seek My face
target: Israel’s repentant turning and appeal to God
vehicle: seeking a person’s face in order to gain audience or favor
physical approach to someone’s visible presence
ground: seeking close presence and favorable regard from someone in authority
desire for audience, acceptance, restored relationship
repentant turning as pursuit of presence
posture: anticipates a future humbled pursuit of restored relationship with God
instances.explanation: To 'seek my face' is an idiomatic metaphor: Israel will, under distress, earnestly pursue God’s presence and favor as one seeks the face of a powerful benefactor.
